io.sphere.sdk.meta

Class QueryDocumentation

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.sphere.sdk.meta.QueryDocumentation

  • public class QueryDocumentation
extends java.lang.Object

    The Query API is for reading specific resources from SPHERE.IO. The resources can be sorted and fetched in batches.

    The successful execution of a Query results in PagedQueryResult of a SPHERE.IO resource or view. While the Query interface just contains information to execute a query, the interface QueryDsl provides also a domain specific language to tune a query.

    For most of the SPHERE.IO resources classes (in a package queries) exist to support you formulating valid queries.

    The following snipped creates a query which selects all products not meaningful ordered.

    final ProductQuery query = new ProductQuery();

    Predicates

    Helper methods for common use cases

    A common use case to query a product is to query it by slug. For this and other most common use cases exist helper methods as shown in the next example.

    final QueryDsl<Product> queryBySlug = new ProductQuery().bySlug(ProductProjectionType.CURRENT, Locale.ENGLISH, "blue-t-shirt");
    You may have noticed that the type of the query is not ProductQuery anymore but QueryDsl which does not contain the method ProductQuery.bySlug(io.sphere.sdk.products.ProductProjectionType, java.util.Locale, String). That is due to the implementation of the domain specific language and still enables you to configure pagination and sorting.

    Important to know is that the QueryDsl uses immutable objects, so the call of ProductQuery.bySlug(io.sphere.sdk.products.ProductProjectionType, java.util.Locale, String) does not change the internal state of the ProductQuery but creates a new QueryDsl object with the selected predicate.

    Self constructed predicates for special cases

    For more advanced queries you have to use the Predicate API. For example querying for some names you can use:

    final Predicate<Product> predicate = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).isOneOf("blue t-shirt", "blue jeans");
final QueryDsl<Product> query = new ProductQuery().withPredicate(predicate);

    The Predicate API looks verbose, but it is it's goal to prevent typos and make it via the IDE discoverable for which attributes can be queried.

    You can still create predicates from strings, but you need to escape characters. 
    final Predicate<Product> safePredicate = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).isOneOf("blue t-shirt", "blue jeans");
final Predicate<Product> unsafePredicate = Predicate.of("masterData(current(name(en in (\"blue t-shirt\", \"blue jeans\"))))");
assertThat(unsafePredicate).isEqualTo(safePredicate);

    For creating predicates for resource <RESOURCE> there is a method model() in a class <RESOURCE>Query.

    Connecting predicates

    For connecting predicates use Predicate.and(io.sphere.sdk.queries.Predicate) and Predicate.or(io.sphere.sdk.queries.Predicate).

    The following example shows a query for a product where either the name is "foo" or the id is "bar".

    final Predicate<Product> nameIsFoo = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).is("foo");
final Predicate<Product> idIsBar = ProductQuery.model().id().is("bar");
final QueryDsl<Product> query = new ProductQuery().withPredicate(nameIsFoo.or(idIsBar));

    To query for two conditions use and. The following example queries for the name foo and the membership in a category with id "cat1".

    final Predicate<Product> nameIsFoo = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).is("foo");
final Reference<Category> category = Category.reference("cat1");
final Predicate<Product> isInCat1 = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().categories().isIn(category);
final QueryDsl<Product> query = new ProductQuery().withPredicate(nameIsFoo.and(isInCat1));

    Since the previous queries have a common path you can formulate a combined query with where, but this is not possible for every entity.

    final Reference<Category> category = Category.reference("cat1");
final Predicate<Product> nameIsFooAndIsInCat1 = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current()
        .where(model -> model.name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).is("foo").and(model.categories().isIn(category)));
final QueryDsl<Product> query = new ProductQuery().withPredicate(nameIsFooAndIsInCat1);

    Negate predicates

    It is not possible to negate complete predicates, but it is possible on the field level. So for example the next query is for products where the name is not exactly "foo". 
    final Predicate<Product> nameIsNotFoo = ProductQuery.model().masterData().current().name().lang(Locale.ENGLISH).isNot("foo");
final QueryDsl<Product> query = new ProductQuery().withPredicate(nameIsNotFoo);
